rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 17   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 5    Value: 10
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 22   Value: 12
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 25   Value: 27
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 5    Value: 34
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I'm currently holding:
- Wheat 17 (value 6)  
- Wood 5 (value 10)  
- Sheep 22 (value 12)  
- Brick 25 (value 27)  
- Ore 5 (value 34)  

Current total value = 17×6 + 5×10 + 22×12 + 25×27 + 5×34  
= 102 + 50 + 264 + 675 + 170 = 1 261.

My most valuable resource is Ore (34 each), but I own only 5 of them—too few to trade away without hurting my total. My least valuable in absolute terms is Wheat (6), but I have lots of it. Sheep (12) is also plentiful, so I can spare a few without much risk.

Brick is worth 27 each and I own 25, so I am already well stocked. I would like to gain more Ore to capitalize on its high unit value.  

I therefore open with an offer to trade my plentiful Sheep for some Ore.

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 0 others -> 2 Ore, 0 others]

rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 17   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 5    Value: 10
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 22   Value: 12
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 25   Value: 27
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 5    Value: 34
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I will first estimate the total pre-trade asset value, then isolate the resource whose expected post-trade value lies furthest below its intrinsic value. Ranking them:

- Brick: 25×27 = 675  
- Sheep: 22×12 = 264  
- Ore:   5×34 = 170  
- Wood:  5×10 = 50  
- Wheat: 17×6  = 102  

Brick is far and away my most valuable holding, so the worst thing would be to give any of it away. Conversely, Brick is probably what the opponent wants most. My surplus low-value items are Wheat and Wood. My best general strategy is therefore:

(a) Never trade away Brick.  
(b) Never trade away Ore unless the per-unit value received is ≥34 (i.e., basically never).  
(c) Be willing to “trade up” Sheep or Wheat/Wood into someone else’s Ore or Brick if the rate is mildly favorable.  

Turn 1

I open with a low-value, wide-margin offer to see the opponent’s stance without risking high-value resources.

[Offer: 8 Wood, 12 Wheat → 4 Sheep]

0.reason: Player 0 made a trade offer in an incorrect format.

1.reason: Player 0 made a trade offer in an incorrect format.
